summary: Michelle, Erin, Clare, James, Orla, Jon and Orla are going to a boy's party. Erin is not sure about it. James tells her to be confident and not be a blowfish. Michelle tells Erin to be sexy.
LLM_scene:
[In Erin’s bedroom. Erin is putting on a dress. Orla is doing her hair. Clare peeks in.]

1. Clare: Erin, you really think you should wear *that* to a boy’s party?

2. Erin: Better than looking like a blowfish, Clare. (frowns at her dress in the mirror)

3. James: (from the doorway) Confidence, Erin! Be bold like a hawk, not stiff like a blowfish.

4. Orla: Ew, James. Nobody wants to be a blowfish.

5. Erin: I’m not sure I want to go, though. A boy’s party sounds… weird.

6. Michelle: Weird? Erin, boy’s party = opportunity. Opportunity to be *sexy*. (strikes a pose)

7. Erin: Sexy? Mum, I’m thirteen. If I try to be sexy, I'll look ridiculous.

8. Michelle: Ridiculous sells, sweetheart. Sometimes ridiculous is the look.

9. Clare: Look, just be yourself. Unless you’re a blowfish. Then pick a look.

10. Orla: And if you're going to be sexy, wear red. Red distracts the eye from bad dancing.

11. James: (rolls his eyes) Are we styling Erin or sending her to battle?

12. Erin: I just don’t want to regret it later. What if I spill something everywhere?

13. Michelle: Spill? Then you’ll clean it up, or someone else will.

14. Jon: (knocks and enters) Hey, girls. You're all ready?

15. Erin: I think so. Or I’m somewhere between sexy and sensible.

16. Jon: That’s perfect. No one notices sensible anyway, Erin. Go with the sexy.

17. James: See? Jon gets it. Confidence, eye contact, smile. Not blowfish.

18. Erin: (sighs) Fine. Eye contact. Smile. And maybe red lips.

19. Orla: Don’t let any boys see your diary tonight either. That’s reserved for your enemies.

20. Clare: Enemy? Who needs enemies when you’ve got siblings?

21. James: Erin, promise me one thing—you’ll dance even if it feels silly.

22. Erin: Promise. (takes a deep breath, fixes her dress) Let’s go make a memory, not a mannequin.

23. Michelle: That’s my girl. Now—smart phone... red lips... strut out that door!
human_scene:
[Night time. Michelle, Erin, Clare, James and Orla sneak out of their room in their pyjamas.]

Erin: I'm not sure about this.

Michelle: I knew you'd fanny out!

Erin: These lads have moves. You said so yourself, Michelle. And I haven't got any moves!

(They walk up the stairs.)

Michelle: Look, let's just get in there, have a few drinks, and just loosen up a bit.

Clare: No! No loosening up! I don't like it!

James: Just be confident, Erin. Boys like that.

Michelle: How the fuck would you know what boys like?

James: Cause I'm a boy, Michelle. I'm a real live boy.

Orla: Aw, yeah, like Pinocchio.

(They reach the boys' door.)

Michelle: (touching Erin's hair) Listen be sexy, okay?

Erin: Sexy, right.

(Erin leans against the wall and pouts.)

Michelle: I said be sexy, not be a fucking blowfish, Erin.

(Erin looks offended and tries to be sexy again. Michelle knocks.)

(Jon opens the door, looking confused.)

James: Hello, mate.

Michelle: We heard you boys are having a party.

Jon: No?

Michelle: Well yous are now.

(They all walk into the room. Orla stares at Jon close to his face. He looks scared.)

summary: Clare hasn't said a word since last night. James is wearing his pink waterproof trousers. He did it for a laugh. Erin and Michelle want to swap Harry.
LLM_scene:
[In the Quinn living room. Clare sits silent on the couch, looking down. James stands nearby in bright pink waterproof trousers, grinning. Erin and Michelle whisper to each other.]

Erin: (whispering, to Michelle) Do you think James knows how much he looks like a… a flaming flamingo?

Michelle: (stifling laughter) I’m not sure. He seems proud of it.

James: (joining in) Come on! These trousers are waterproof. I could stomp through a flood and still keep my dignity.

Erin: Dignity? In pink that loud? I’d hear you from the moon, lad.

Mary: (offstage, calling) Michelle! Erin! Why are you two sneaking around like you're planning a bank heist?

Michelle: (boldly) Mammy, we want to swap Harry.

Mary: Swap Harry? What are you on about?

Erin: Harry from Friends Across the Barricades. You know, Michelle’s crush.

Michelle: We figured if Erin gets Harry, I get... well, someone else.

Mary: (exasperated) You can’t just swap people like you swap sandwiches!

James: (poking in) What about me? Am I part of this trade?

Erin: (ignoring him) Clare, you’re not talking. You’re not even blinking. What’s wrong?

[Clare lifts her head slowly. She opens mouth to speak.]

Erin: Speak, Clare. We can’t make plans in the dark.

Clare: (softly) I…I heard everything last night.

[Silence. Erin and Michelle exchange a look.]

Michelle: (concerned) About Harry?

Clare: About you all… about everything.

[In the pause, James stands firm, pink trousers glinting under lights. Erin looks torn; Michelle hopes.]

Erin: Then we need to talk. All of us together. This swapping nonsense stops unless everyone's okay.

Mary: (entering room) Finally, some sense returning.

[Scene ends.]
human_scene:
[The next day, on a hill in a field.]

Erin: (to Michelle) What's wrong with Clare? She hasn't said two words since last night.

Michelle: Well, I'm not complaining.

(Orla is clutching onto Jon. James is wearing his pink waterproof trousers.)

James: I just did it for a laugh. The trousers. I'll do anything for a laugh, me. I'm mad like that.

(Orla shoves James.)

Jon: Right.

Michelle: All right, there they are.

Erin: Okay, if we're gonna do this, Michelle, we need to do it delicately.

Michelle: Of course. Oi! Lads! We want to swap!

Erin: (annoyed) Brilliant!

Dee: Swap?

Michelle: Yeah. Erin's gonna have Harry now and I'm gonna have you, all right?

(They say nothing.)

Michelle: Great stuff. (gives thumbs up)

summary: The Child of Prague statue that the Bishop gifted to Our Lady Immaculate College was passed around the Derry Diocese. Sister Patrick has left the school for a missionary work in Belfast. Ms. De Brn is the new English teacher.
LLM_scene:
[In the school corridor. Erin and Orla are waiting outside their English classroom. Erin clutches a small prayer card.]

ERIN: I still can’t believe the Statue of the Child of Prague is here in school. Did you hear Ms. De Brn got it from the Bishop himself?

ORLA: Aye—just passed around the Derry Diocese like a holy hot potato.  

ERIN: It’s supposed to bring good luck. Maybe it’ll bless my essays, finally.

ORLA: Or maybe Ms. De Brn will use it as a punishment. “Miss a comma, thou shalt not pass.”

(Ms. De Brn opens the door.)

MS. DE BRN: Good morning, girls. Hope you’re ready for English—today we begin poetry.

ERIN: Morning, Ms. De Brn. Will the Child of Prague help us with rhymes, do you think?

MS. DE BRN: Possibly. But I expect you to work as hard as if you were standing in front of him.

ORLA: Even if we mess up, he might forgive us?

MS. DE BRN: With enough effort, yes. But I’m not a saint.

(They enter classroom; Sister Michael is inside placing the statue on a shelf.)

SISTER MICHAEL: Classes are about to begin. I’d like to remind everyone Sister Patrick will not be returning—her missionary work in Belfast starts next week.

ERIN (whispering to Orla): That’s where all the drama is, right?

ORLA: Belfast... the big leagues of trouble.

MARY: (offstage, calling through window) Erin! Don’t forget your blazer! And who’s taking care of the Child of Prague during Georgina’s lockdown?

GERRY: (following Mary) I saw him—statue’s safe. Sister Michael’s minding him.

ERIN: Thank God. I couldn't live with myself if the Bishop got word that we lost his Baby Jesus.

MS. DE BRN: Now, for today’s poem: explore injustice. Compare your knee-jerk reactions to suffering—Saints, statues, and school alike.

ORLA: (to Erin) This’ll be good. Maybe I’ll write about that time Mammy banned us from the bridge.

ERIN: That, and how Sister Declan died... except almost ninety-eight didn’t stop us freaking out.

MS. DE BRN: Excellent material. You two—pull up chairs. And remember—violence is less helpful than understanding. Even for statuary.
human_scene:
[In the assembly hall at school.]

Sister Michael: As you all know, at the beginning of term, the Bishop graciously bestowed a beautiful piece of religious art onto Our Lady Immaculate College, the enchanting Child of Prague.

(She pulls away a piece of fabric to reveal the statue.)

(James looks deeply confused.)

Sister Michael: There we are. Sure, isn't he a great fella altogether?

James: I still don't get what it's supposed to be.

Michelle: It's Jesus as a wain.

James: (tilting his head) Why's he got a big red hat on?

Michelle: Nobody knows.

Sister Michael: It was the Bishop's wish that he be passed around all the schools in the Derry Diocese. Therefore we are joined this morning by Mr. Malone, headmaster of St. Benedict's, so that the handover ceremony can take place. You are very welcome, Mr. Malone. Though I fear you may have had a wasted journey. I've thought about it, and I'd much rather just hold onto him, actually. (she smiles) He brightens up my office. (sternly) He doesn't answer back.

(The kids look awkward.)

Sister Michael: I like the fella. And if the Bishop has a problem with that, he can take it up with me. Now, what else was there? (she takes a sheet of paper) Ah, yes. Sadly, Sister Patrick has decided to leave us.

(Erin yawns.)

Sister Michael: She's returning to her missionary work, educating the heathen inhabitants of a primitive and savage place.

Woman: She's taking a teaching post in Belfast, Sister.

Sister Michael: Precisely. The Board of Governors promised me that her replacement would arrive today, but as usual they were talking out of their

(Door bangs. Sister Michael looks up. New English teacher, Ms. De Brn stands at the back of the hall with a helmet in her hand.)

Ms. De Brn: I believe you've been expecting me.

(The students all look shocked and excited. Orla shakes her head.)

Sister Michael: (rolling her eyes) Here we go.

summary: Erin is writing a love story for her partner. She is frustrated that she has to explain the meaning of the word "bide" to Michelle and James.
LLM_scene:
[In Erin’s bedroom. Erin sits at her desk, writing in a notebook. Michelle knocks and enters.]

Michelle: What’re you writing, Erin?

Erin: It’s a love story... for someone special.

[James slips in behind Michelle.]

James: Ah, romance! Are you going to read it out loud?

Erin: Not yet. I just used a word and they’re asking me what it means.

Michelle: Which word? Is it one of those posh words like “beguile” or something?

Erin: No—it’s “bide.” I wrote: “He will bide with her until dawn.”

Michelle: Bide...? What does that even mean? Stay? Wait?

Erin: Exactly, sort of. “Bide” means to stay somewhere or remain somewhere for a time… to wait.

James: So like when Dad says he’ll bide till the craic’s over before going home?

Erin: Yes, James, exactly like that—but in a romantic way, not your da’s pub habits.

[Mary sticks her head in the door.]

Michelle: Mam, can you help? What does “bide” mean?

Mary: “Bide” is like when you wait for something good—you don’t rush it. You stay patient, you hope.

Erin: Thank you, Mam. Finally someone gets it.

James: So in your story, the lad bides with the lass because he’s waiting for love, not because he’s stuck?

Erin: Precisely! Get your brains in gear, James.

Michelle: Right, now I understand. Go on, read more!
human_scene:
[In the Quinn kitchen. The kids are eating junk food and writing.]

Clare: (frustrated) God, this whole writing-from-the-soul carry-on is a nightmare.

James: I know.

Michelle: What rhymes with ride?

Clare: Bide.

Michelle: Bide? What the fuck does bide mean? Bide. That's not a word.

Clare: It is a word, Michelle.

Michelle: Bide? You've pure made that up.

Erin: Can we all be quiet? Please.

Orla: (holding up a picture she drew of James) What do you think, James? You've got red eyes cause I ran out of brown.

James: My eyes are green.

Orla: Now you tell me. (she looks distraught)

Erin: Okay. So, I'm trying not to think too much. Just to sort of let it flow through me.

Michelle: Aw, that's minging Erin.

Erin: (annoyed) Here's what I have so far. You know we belong together, you and I, forever and ever. No matter where you are, you're my guiding star.

James: Isn't that the theme tune to Home and Away?

Erin: Is it? (frustrated) Aw, for God's sake!

summary: Erin, James, Michelle, Orla and Clare have just known Ms. De Brn for two days and they love her. She invited them to her house at night.
LLM_scene:
[Evening. De Brún’s living room. Soft lamplight. Erin, James, Michelle, Orla, and Clare sit on a worn couch and armchairs. De Brún enters with tea tray.]

De Brún: (smiling) Here we are. Hot tea and biscuits. Nothing too fancy—just us.

Erin: (accepting cup) Thanks, Ms. De Brún. This is lovely.

Clare: This house feels so warm. Like it’s breathing.

Michelle: I like your curtains, Ms. De Brún. They’re purple—but not too scary purple.

James: (peeking at photos on mantelpiece) Who’s that man in the sailing boat?

De Brún: That’s my father. He loved boats. Used to take me out every summer.

Orla: You’re lucky. My grandma once took me on a paddleboat. I almost drowned.

Erin: Orla! You’re always dramatic.

Orla: A little drama is good. It keeps the heart beating.

De Brún: (laughs) Would anyone like more tea? Or perhaps some hot chocolate?

Michelle: Hot chocolate, please! With marshmallows if you have them.

James: Yes! Marshmallows are essential to any evening.

Clare: I’ll have tea, thank you.

Erin: Hot chocolate for me too.

[De Brún pours drinks, handing them out.]

De Brún: So, tell me honestly—what do you like about me so far?

Erin: (considering) You’re... different. You listen.

Michelle: And you don’t always punish us. You talk.

James: You laugh. And sometimes you let us choose the music.

Orla: You don’t judge. Even when we fight, you don’t take sides. That’s nice.

De Brún: (quietly) Thank you. That means more than you know.

Clare: It’s weird—just two days. Feels like I’ve always known you.

Erin: Me too. I was braced for lectures, uniforms, rules. Instead, you let us be.

[Door creaks. De Brún pauses.]

De Brún: Shall I put on some music?

Erin: Yes! Something rock or Gaelic or—

Michelle: Anything but funeral dirge.

Orla: (grinning) Or opera. Let opera surprise us!

[De Brún presses play; gentle guitar strumming begins. The room softens.]

De Brún: There, just some acoustic folk. Thought it might suit the moment.

James: It suits. Feels… peaceful.

Erin: (raising her mug) To new beginnings. And to you, Ms. De Brún.

Everyone: To Ms. De Brún.

[They clink mugs. Music plays. Moments of comfortable silence.]

Clare: Will we do this again? Night at yours?

De Brún: Of course, Clare. My door’s always open.

Erin: (smiling) Then tonight, I think I just found a home away from home.

De Brún: And I’m honored to share it with all of you.
human_scene:
[On the street at night.]

Erin: Ms. De Brn's amazing. I've just never met anyone like her.

James: She's an inspiration.

Clare: Absolutely.

Michelle: She really knows how to grab things by the balls!

Clare: Oh yeah!

(Orla looks confused.)

Erin: She's changed my life, she really has.

James: (beaming) She likes my accent.

Orla: I'd die for her.

Erin: I think I would too, you know.

James: Me, too.

Michelle: Aye, fuck it. Why not?

Clare: Yeah! I mean, obviously, I totally agree, I'd die for her as well, but I'm also conscious of the fact that we've only known her, like, two days.

Erin: And?

Clare: Well, is it a bit weird she's invited us round to her house at night?

Erin: What do you mean?

Clare: Well, she's a teacher.

Erin: She's much more than a teacher.

Clare: Yeah. No. Obviously. I get that. She's great, but it's just that I've a feeling it might be, sort of, frowned upon.

Erin: God, Clare. You're so conditioned.

Clare: What's that supposed to mean?

Michelle: It means you need to loosen the fuck up.

Clare: I am loose, thank you very much.

Michelle: Face it, Clare, you're a craic killer.

Clare: (stops walking) I'm not a craic killer.

(The others walk on.)

Clare: I am not a craic killer!!

summary: Clare was at Ms. De Brn's house at night. She was drunk. Jenny Joyce and Erin are on the street.
LLM_scene:
[On a dimly lit Belfast street late at night. Erin and Jenny Joyce are standing outside a house, waiting.]

1. Jenny Joyce: Do you think she’s okay in there, Erin?

2. Erin: (frowning) She stank of drink when I left her. I don’t know about okay, Jes.

3. Jenny Joyce: Maybe she just needed to get away. Ms. De Brn’s place has a fire in the fireplace. Warm.

4. Erin: Warm’s one thing. But her tears were warm too. Real hot.

5. Jenny Joyce: (scoffs) You and Clare, you two are cut from the same cloth, Erin. Reckless, stubborn.

6. Erin: Reckless? Maybe. But I won’t just leave her to sober up alone in someone else’s house.

7. Jenny Joyce: What if Ms. De Brn kicks us out? She’s strict about visitors this late.

8. Erin: Better kicked out than worrying ourselves sick. Come on.

[They both approach the front door. Erin lifts her fist to knock.]

9. Erin: (shouts) Clare! You in there? It’s Erin!

10. (Silence. A faint giggle comes from inside.)

11. Jenny Joyce: She’s laughing, Jen. That ain’t a good thing.

12. Erin: (voice shaking) Clare… open up. Jaysus, you’re scaring me.

13. (Door creaks. Clare appears in the doorway, dishevelled, eyes red.)

14. Clare: Erin. Jes. Don’t come in. I’m fine.

15. Erin: You’re not fine. You’re swaying like a lamppost in wind.

16. Claire: It’s just the drink talking. I’ll sleep it off.

17. Jenny Joyce: Then we’ll be right here till you sober up. We’ve got mad notions of responsibility now, Erin.

[Erin places a steadying arm around Clare’s shoulder as Jenny Joyce looks on anxiously.]
human_scene:
[On the street.]

(Clare is drunk.)

Clare: I feel all floaty.

Michelle: She's absolutely fucking flying.

(Jenny Joyce appears.)

Jenny: Well, well, well. What are you guys up to?

Erin: Nothing much.

Clare: We've just been hanging out at Ms. De Brn's house.

Jenny: You were at her house? At night? Well, that's a bit inappropriate.

Clare: Your ma is a bit inappropriate.

Jenny: That doesn't even make sense.

Clare: Your ma doesn't even make sense.

Jenny: Is she drunk?

Clare: Your ma's drunk.

Erin: Okay, Clare. I think we get the idea. Lovely seeing you, Jenny.

Michelle: Take care now.

(They walk away.)

summary: Ms. De Brn is no longer in the class. Sister Michael will be taking this class for the rest of the term.
LLM_scene:
[Scene: The Quinn kitchen. Orla is at the table doing homework. Erin bursts in, backpack slung over shoulder. Mary is brewing tea. Granda Joe is sitting reading the paper.]

Erin: Mammy! Did you hear? Sister Michael’s taking our class now – for the rest of the term!

Mary: (startled) What? Is that proper?

Orla: (without looking up) Oh great. More nuns. As if one wasn’t enough.

Erin: I thought Ms. De Brn was harsh but—Sister Michael sings hymns in detention now. Hymns!

Granda Joe: Aye, but she might be better than that old git Ms. De Brn, God rest her soul.

Mary: Let’s not speak ill of the gone, Gerald.

[Cut to: Classroom. Sister Michael at the front, chalk in hand. Students murmur. Erin and Clare sit together.]

Sister Michael: Settle down, children. As you know, I will be teaching you for the rest of the term.

Clare: (whispering to Erin) Any idea where Ms. De Brn’s gone?

Erin: Dunno. Probably politics. Or hiding from us lot.

Sister Michael: Today’s lesson is poetry. I want each of you to write about something you care deeply about.

Orla: (in thought) Conflict? Identity? The bridge? Bombs?

Erin: (leans over) Don’t you dare write about bombs again. I’ve done enough trauma.

Sister Michael: Erin, your voice is important. If you want to write about bombs, write about your truth.

[Back in kitchen: Mary wiping a teacup. Gerry enters, looking dishevelled.]

Gerry: What chaos in there? I swear the school sounded like a cathedral full of banshees.

Mary: That’s Sister Michael for you. She’s moved mountains in that class already.

Granda Joe: (smirks) Mountains, or hymns. Same thing to my ears.

Gerry: Sure, at least there’s no Ms. De Brn lurking behind every desk, breathing down their necks.

Mary: Let’s hope this Sister Michael doesn’t go all Ms. De Brn on them.

[Back in classroom.]

Erin: (writing) …“In the silence between bombs I hear hope…” No, too lofty.

Sister Michael: Beautiful, Erin. Don’t censor your heart.

Orla: (quietly) Maybe this term won’t be such a disaster after all.

[Erin glances at Orla, slightly moved.]

Erin: (softly) Maybe not.
human_scene:
[In the English classroom. The kids walk in.]

(Sister Michael is wiping Ms. De Brn's name off the blackboard. Erin's face drops.)

Sister Michael: Take a seat please, ladies.

Erin: Where's Ms. De Brn?

Sister Michael: Gone. And she's not coming back.

Erin: What?!

Clare: I knew it. When I woke up this morning, I had a feeling something terrible was going to happen and also that essentially, deep down, I'm quite an evil person.

Michelle: It's called a hangover, Clare. You'll be grand.

Sister Michael: I will be taking this class for the rest of the term, which makes me want to pull off my own face, but needs must.

Erin: (to Jenny) This was you, wasn't it? What did you do? What did you say?

Jenny: I don't know what you're talking about.

Erin: Aye, so you don't. Supergrass!

Sister Michael: That's quite enough!

Erin: You don't understand, Sister. Ms. De Brn, she touched us.

Sister Michael: What?

Erin: She made us think, she made us feel.

Sister Michael: (sighing) Oh, thank God! That would be all I need.

Erin: You can't sack her! You just can't!

(Clare drops her head into her hand, in pain.)

Sister Michael: (walking towards Erin) Miss Quinn, you appear to be under the misapprehension that you can address me as though you are my equal! I suggest you rein it in, and take a seat.

(The kids sit down and Jenny smiles with satisfaction.)

summary: The kids walk with their bags. They need to go south-east for 0.5 miles and will receive further instructions shortly.
LLM_scene:
[Outside Erin’s house. Erin and Orla are each shoulder-strapping backpacks. Morning light.]

Erin: Are you sure there’s no breakfast first?

Orla: There’s a banana in my bag. Your Ma made the toast.

Erin: Fine. (slings bag) South-east for half a mile, she said. Then wait. More instructions.

Orla: Why south-east though? Why not just go east?

Erin: She’s always fancied compass points. Learned them during the Troubles, she says.

[They step off the porch and begin walking down the lane.]

Mary: (from doorway) Girls! Did you pack enough socks?

Erin: (calling back) Socks are in, Ma! And two bottles of water.

Mary: Good. And stay together. Whatever comes next.

Orla: (quietly) Erin, what if the instructions are stupid?

Erin: We’ll make them less stupid. That’s what we’re good at.

[They round the corner and head along a narrow road toward south-east.]

Orla: I hate marches like this. All this walking and nobody telling you when it's going to end.

Erin: Think of it like a treasure hunt. With imminent danger.

Orla: That’s ___ comforting.

[They walk past a row of closed shops, bags heavy on shoulders.]

Erin: Half a mile isn’t far. Shouldn’t take more than ten minutes.

Orla: And then?

Erin: Then we wait. Maybe messages. Maybe people. Whoever.

Orla: Promise we’ll go home if it gets mad dangerous?

Erin: I promise. Nothing’s worth risking you.

Orla: Thanks. (smiles) Now hurry up—I’m lagging behind.

[They continue walking, fading into the quiet street as the sky lightens.]
human_scene:
[On the street. The kids walk with their bags.]

Michelle: We're doing it for peace, all right, Mary. A piece of that fine Protestant ass!

(Erin and Michelle high-five excitedly.)

Clare: (disgusted) God, you are such a hypocrite, Erin.

Erin: No, I'm not. I just don't think there's anything wrong with some cross-community

Michelle: Fiddling.

Erin: Relations.

Orla: (looking at a map) So we need to head south-east for 0.5 miles and you'll receive further instructions shortly.

Erin: We haven't even left the estate yet, Orla.

Michelle: These Prods have some serious moves up their sleeves, you know. They're not as fucked up about sex as we are. They've put the work in. They know what they're doing.

Clare: They're people, Michelle. They're not sex toys.

Michelle: I beg to differ.

James: I'm really looking forward to making friends with some lads. (smiling)

Michelle: Lads aren't going to make friends with you, James. Lads make friends with other lads.

James: I am a lad.

Erin: Aye, so you are, James.

Clare: (taking money out of her pocket) Okay, how much money do we have?

Michelle: Look, the riding of the Protestants is one thing, but I don't see why we have to buy them a present. I mean they already have all the land, all the jobs and all the fucking rights.

Erin: Aye, Michelle. That's definitely the attitude we should have entering into this weekend.

summary: Dennis is out of stock of a present for Protestants. Clare, Erin, Michelle, Orla, James and Erin want him to give them the Subbuteo and pay them off in instalments.
LLM_scene:
[In Dennis’s front room. Erin, Clare, Michelle, Orla, and James are gathered; Erin holds a half-empty Subbuteo box.]

Erin: Dennis! Where’s the rest of the Subbuteo set you promised for Protestants?

Dennis: I’m sorry—out of stock. They’ve none left in Belfast, Derry—nowhere.

Clare: Out of stock?! You told us you had it yesterday!

Michelle: Yeah. And I’ve been counting on that magic midfield player since yesterday.

James: You promised instalments, too—now I’ve spent my pocket money on nothing but promise.

Orla: Instalments, instalments—they sound just like a loan shark in shiny shoes, but we’ll take it.

Erin: So what do we do? Keep waiting? You’ll buy it, or…?

Dennis: I could find a similar set from a second-hand shop but it won’t be official.

Clare: Official? Dennis, we don’t need fancy. We need Subbuteo. Protestants won’t care if it’s chipped.

Orla: As long as we can pretend it’s new at school.

James: And we still get the players in the right kits, right? No funny colours.

Dennis: Maybe. But it'll cost more. I can give you the instalment plan—half now, half later.

Erin: Fine. I’ll take half now. Michelle?

Michelle: Half now for me too. Clare? You okay with late payment?

Clare: I’ll scrape together what I can. Work at the shop this weekend.

Orla: I can help too—babysit Mrs. McCall’s dog. Any dog-sitting counts as Subbuteo fund.

James: Right. When are we paying you the rest, Dennis?

Dennis: Two weeks. Okay? Two weeks and the rest is due.

Erin: And you get us the boxes then?

Dennis: If I can. If they’re back in stock.

Orla: If not, you find another way. We’ll not be out-played.

Erin: Right. Deal.

(All nod, some reluctantly clutching coins, others sharing hopeful glances.)

[They disperse, Erin lingering, staring at Dennis.]

Erin: Thanks, Dennis. And don’t let us down. I’ve got dreams of scoring on Rory Crawford.

Dennis: I’ll not let you down, Erin. I promise.

(Erin exits; Dennis sighs, glances at the empty space once occupied by the Subbuteo set.)
human_scene:
[In Dennis' Wee Shop.]

Dennis: A present for Protestants.

(They all stare back at him. Clare, Erin and Michelle are all eating sweets.)

Dennis: Ah, now, my next Protestant gift delivery isn't due to arrive until Wednesday, and as it stands I'm completely out of stock, what with there being such a high fucking demand for that sort of thing around these parts.

Orla: (turning to the others) That's a shame.

Clare: (enthusiastically pointing) How much for the Subbuteo, Dennis?

Dennis: We'll call it sixteen quid.

(James looks shocked.)

James: Could we call it 1.76?

Dennis: No, we fucking couldn't.

Erin: How about, we give you the 1.76 and pay the rest off in instalments?

Clare: Yeah, which would be what? 3.56 over four weeks?

Dennis: Jesus, check out Rain Wain.

Erin: Or, you could give us the Subbuteo and then we work off the debt?

Clare: (sucking on sweet) Yeah, we could do chores and stuff.

Dennis: Chores? What do you think this is? Little House on the Fucking Prairie?

Orla: (smiling) Do you watch Little House on the Prairie, Dennis?

Dennis: (suddenly furious) Get out!

(The kids look taken aback as they walk out.)

summary: Jenny and Aisling are going to buy a present for the Protestants. Jenny is good friends with a half-Protestant girl whose name's Zara and she has a horse.
LLM_scene:
[In Jenny’s bedroom. Aisling is rummaging through Jenny’s wardrobe.]

Jenny: What are you doing, Aisling?

Aisling: Trying to find something decent to wear. If we’re going to the shops to pick out a present for the Protestants, I’m not going looking like this.

Jenny: It doesn’t have to be fancy, just respectful. Zara’ll be coming with us.

Aisling: Half-Protestant, yeah? Doesn’t that count?

Jenny: It does. But you know her Mam likes tradition. We’ll need something that says “peace offering,” not “you’re culture’s crap.”

[They head downstairs. Jenny’s Mam, Siobhan, is making tea.]

Siobhan: You off to the shops?

Jenny: We are, Mam. We’re buying a present. For Zara’s Protestant part of the family.

Siobhan: (sips tea) Bridging the divide, are we?

Aisling: Something like that. Jenny’s being very grown up.

Jenny: She’s good friends with Zara. And her horse—Donny—he’d love treats too. Maybe we get something horsey.

Siobhan: Just stay away from anything that’ll start an argument, girls.

[On the street. Jenny and Aisling, walking. Zara meets them, tied to her horse Donny under a hedge.]

Zara: Hey! Ready to shop?

Jenny: Aye. We thought maybe stable stuff for Donny. And something for you and your family.

Aisling: But not too “Protestant,” or they’ll think we’re mocking them.

Zara: My Dad likes oak things. Protestant or not, he loves woodwork.

Jenny: Oak. Good. Solid.

[They reach the market. Wooden crafts stall.]

Aisling: Look at that, oak photo frame.

Jenny: Could put a picture of Zara and Donny in it.

Zara: I have that photo! (Pulls out phone) It’s lovely.

Vendor: Ah, you girls need help deciding?

Jenny: Yes please. Something meaningful.

Vendor: Perhaps this oak bread board—solid, handmade. Symbol of unity, sharing.

Aisling: That could work.

Zara: That’d be perfect for their kitchen.

Jenny: And Donny? What about some carrots?

Vendor: (smirks) Not with me, lass. But there’s a feed stall just down.

Jenny: Right. Let’s get this board, and pick up carrots after.

[They pay, board wrapped. Exit stall.]

Aisling: I think your Dad will like it, Zara.

Zara: And Donny will be nobbled with joy.

Jenny: See? Peace and carrots. Maybe this is what ‘Friends Across the Barricades’ really means.

Aisling: (smiling) Exactly. A gift, a horse, some hope.

[They walk off, Jenny carrying the oak board, Zara leading Donny.]

Zara: Thank you, Jenny. This means a lot.

Jenny: Anytime. Let’s go get Donny’s treats then.

Aisling: And maybe a cuppa after?

Jenny: You read my mind.
human_scene:
[On a road. The kids are walking.]

Clare: Come on girls, this is embarrassing!

Michelle: Well, it's all right for you Clare, but we want to buck these lads. We have to offer them some kind of incentive.

Clare: They're not prostitutes, Michelle! And even if they were, I think a half-eaten packet of Rolos and an Ulster Bank key ring is a pretty insulting form of payment.

James: (smiling and holding up a pencil) I have a HB pencil!

Michelle: (taking the pencil) Happy days.

(Jenny and Aisling appear, holding a large present wrapped carefully.)

Jenny: Hi, guys!

Erin: That's not That's not what you're giving to the Protestants, is it?

Jenny: It's just a little token, really.

Orla: Yeah. So's ours.

Aisling: Is that an Ulster Bank key ring?

Erin: It is indeed, yep.

Jenny: I must admit, I had a bit of an advantage when it came to the whole present buying thing, because

Michelle: You're loaded.

Jenny: Because I know what they like. (smiling smugly) I happen to be very good friends with a half-Protestant.

Clare: What?

Michelle: They don't come in halves, Jenny.

Jenny: They do actually. I met her at ballet class. Her name's zara, and she has a horse.

Erin: Good for zara. Bye bye now.

(They all walk away from Jenny and Aisling.)

Clare: (annoyed) Of course she's friends with a half-Protestant! Of course she is!

Michelle: She has been fucking unbearable since them braces came off.

Erin: Dose.

Clare: (frantically) Well, I'm going to make friends with a full Protestant! See how she likes it. zara won't seem quite so impressive next to my thorough-bred, will she Jenny?!

Erin: Relax, Clare.

Michelle: Why has she got so much money, anyway? Who's her da? Pierce fucking Brosnan?

Erin: He's a surgeon over at Altnagelvin. He took Orla's tonsils out. (climbs into bus)

Orla: And not a day goes by when I don't think about them.

summary: Sister Michael, Jenny, Aisling and Michelle are getting off the bus. The Protestant bus has arrived. The headmistress and the Protestant boys get off in a single file. Sister Michael meets Miss Taylor, who is a Catholic.
LLM_scene:
[Outside school gates. Sister Michael, Jenny, Aisling and Michelle are stepping off a Catholic school bus.]

Michelle: Did you see that one with the bright hair?

Aisling: Shh! You’ll get Sister Michael in trouble.

Jenny: Relax, it’s just a scratch of colour. Makes life interesting.

Sister Michael: Girls, straighten your uniforms. We walk in dignity even when chaos looms.

[The Protestant bus pulls up. Headmistress and Protestant boys disembark in a single file.]

Protestant Boy 1: Morning, Sister.

Protestant Boy 2: Good day, ma’am.

Headmistress: We trust you had a safe journey.

Sister Michael: Indeed. God’s peace be with you all.

[Miss Taylor emerges from the Protestant bus line, neatly dressed.]

Miss Taylor: Sister Michael, lovely to see you this morning.

Sister Michael: Miss Taylor, you’re looking well.

Miss Taylor: Thank you. Always a pleasure to greet kind faces before the day begins.

Jenny: (whispering to Aisling) She always smells of lavender, doesn’t she?

Aisling: More like lily-of-the-valley. Lavender makes me sneeze.

Michelle: Who cares, as long as she doesn’t make us do extra homework.

Miss Taylor: How are the girls? Jenny, Aisling, Michelle?

Jenny: Fine, Miss Taylor. Just about ready for another glorious day in holy captivity.

Miss Taylor: (smiling) Well phrased.

Sister Michael: We will teach them not just lessons from books, but lessons of compassion.

Headmistress: A noble endeavour, Sister Michael. Diocese business calls—boys, carry on.

[Protestant boys file off towards their building.]

Sister Michael: Miss Taylor, after school?

Miss Taylor: I should like that very much.
human_scene:
[Getting off the bus.]

Jenny and Aisling: No hate! No hate! Let's integrate!

(Sister Michael steps out.)

Sister Michael: Kill me.

(The Protestant bus drives in.)

Michelle: (smiling) The Prods have landed!

(Everyone looks excited. The headmistress and the Protestant boys start stepping out.)

Miss Taylor: Single file!

(The boys line up outside the bus.)

Sister Michael: (walking over to headmistress) You must be Miss Taylor?

Miss Taylor: That's right. Well, Janet.

Sister Michael: Michael. Sister Michael.

(They shake hands coldly.)

Miss Taylor: It's a pleasure.

Sister Michael: I know.

Miss Taylor: (to the Protestants) Move it.

Sister Michael: (to the Catholics) Shift it.

(The kids all start walking inside the building.)

Miss Taylor: Why's everyone so desperate for them to mix? I think we should keep them separate.

Sister Michael: (looking impressed) I think we should keep them in cages.

(They exchange evil smirks.)

summary: Rita ordered Michelle, Erin and Clare to move a dead sheep. Rita is back in the van, drinking beer and watching the girls happily. Erin is scared of Rita and doesn't want to help. Michelle, Clare and James decide to make James do it.
LLM_scene:
[Outside on a farm track. A dead sheep lies on the ground. Rita is perched in the back of a rusty van, sipping a beer. Michelle, Erin, Clare, and James stand nearby.]

1. Rita: (yells from van) Right! Get that bleedin’ sheep in the trailer! And I want it done before sundown!

2. Erin: (backs away) No way, Rita. I’m not touchin’ that thing. It’s… it’s horrible.

3. Clare: Erin, stop being dramatic. It’s just a sheep. Dead, yes, but just a sheep.

4. Michelle: Erin’s not moving, Rita. We’ll need someone else on it.

5. James: (gulps) Me? I’m only six, Michelle! I’m too small!

6. Rita: (shouts) Don’t care how old you are, James. Pick it up. I paid good money for this trailer.

7. Erin: (to Clare) You do it then. You love animals so much on Instagram, Clare. Put your hands where your mouth is.

8. Clare: Erin, that’s not fair. I’ll pass on stroking sheep corpses today.

9. Michelle: Look, everybody’s frozen. James, you'll do it. Two hands under its belly, drag while Clare pushes from the back.

10. James: (wobbles closer) Alright… but it smells awful. Rita, you ought to see this!

11. Erin: (nervous, backing further) And if I faint, Rita? What happens then?

12. Rita: (laughs) Then you wake up, Erin. Now MOVE!

13. Clare: Come on, James, I’ll help with the pushing. Erin, you can be the spotter — stand behind so you’re not too near the gore.

14. Erin: (reluctantly steps back) Fine. I’ll be … the spotter. But I’m warning you – if I see even a bit of wool, I might puke.

15. Michelle: That’s the spirit. Now one… two… three! (James and Clare hoist the sheep)

16. Rita: (from van, raising her beer) That’s it! Good lads and lassie. Happy now?

17. James: (panting) Happy? My arms are gonna fall off. But… yeah. Happy enough, Rita.
human_scene:
[Time lapse. Rita is back in the van, drinking beer and watching the girls happily.]

(The girls move the dead sheep.)

Michelle: This is rank!

Clare: Why are we doing it?

Erin: Because Rita told us to, and I'm scared of her, Clare! I'm very, very scared of her! Why's it so heavy? Aren't they meant to be 90% wool?!

Michelle: Just put your back into it! The sooner this is done, the sooner we're back in the van and on our way to see Robbie.

Clare: Robie! I mean, it so obviously doesn't look right!

Erin: I am not getting back in that van, Michelle! The woman is a maniac!

Michelle: We've come this far now, we're not turning back! Oh, Jesus Christ!

Erin: What is it?

Michelle: Oh, I just put my hand on its hole!

(They all freak out.)

Michelle: Fuck this, let's just make James do it, the lazy bastard.

Clare: Totally. Good idea.

(They drop the sheep.)

Clare: (looking around) Where is James?

(Erin looks at her with worry.)

summary: Rita, Erin, Clare, Michelle, Orla and Orla are going to a Take That concert. They are arguing whether or not to go back for James, who has the tickets.
LLM_scene:
[Outside the house. Rita, Erin, Clare, Michelle, Orla are crammed into a car. Music blasts. Everyone excited—except Erin.]

Rita: Are you sure James is going to arrive on time with the tickets?

Erin: He said he’d be here by six. It’s quarter past.

Clare: He promised though. He’s never missed a gig yet.

Michelle: Except that one time when he lost his phone on the bus.

Orla: Yes, but that was different. That phone was practically a brick.

Rita: Well, we can’t just wait here all night. Take That won’t wait for James.

Erin: Maybe we go back. Pick him up.

Clare: What? Drive back through all that traffic just for one lad?

Michelle: Have you seen the queues lately? It’ll add another hour at least.

Orla: But if he doesn’t have the tickets, none of us gets in.

Rita: True. Or someone needs to stay behind. One of us can’t miss out.

Erin: I’ll stay. I can try talking them into letting me in without a ticket.

Clare: You think that’s going to work? With security?

Michelle: I’d volunteer, but I’ve got Mum’s fancy shoes and they’ll be ruined.

Orla: I could stay. I’m already in my trainers.

Rita: No—look, we split. Half go on to the venue. Half stay and fetch James.

Erin: That’s madness. We leave you lot alone? You’ll never make it in time.

Clare: And what if James is driving? We’ll be stuck without him.

Michelle: Unless he phones... Oh wait, battery’s probably dead.

Orla: We could text until the phone dies.

Rita: Decision time. We either go back now or gamble.

Erin: I say we gamble. We can’t lose much.

Clare: We’ll lose the best view, that’s what.

Michelle: And maybe the chance to scream when they hit “Back for Good”.

Orla: Exactly. It’s the chorus. The best chorus.

Rita: Erin, Clare, Michelle—you're sure you want to risk it?

Erin: Yes. Yes, gamble.

Clare: Aye, gamble.

Michelle: Fine by me.

Orla: (sighs) If you lot are going on ahead, I’ll stay behind with Rita to get James.

Rita: Right. We’ll drive off in five. Those going ahead—stay close to the stage.

Erin: Deal. Best of luck, Rita.

Clare: Don’t mess this up, James.

Michelle: We’ll see you at the gate if not inside.

(They share quick smiles. Erin, Clare, Michelle rev engines; Rita and Orla watch as the car pulls away.)
human_scene:
[In the van.]

(The girls all shout at the same time in panic. Rita smokes.)

Rita: Will you shut the fuck up?!

(They all stop shouting.)

Rita: Okay. So, as far as I can make out, you think you left this James character with the gypsies?

Erin: Travellers.

Rita: The small, annoying one thinks we should go back for him, because?

Clare: (panicking) They were so angry with us. He could be in real danger, Rita!

Rita: And the mouthy, curly one thinks we shouldn't, because?

Michelle: Because he's a dickhead, Rita.

Rita: See, it's tricky.

Clare: Oh, come on, Michelle!

Michelle: If we go back for him we're going to miss the start of the concert.

Erin: But he's your cousin.

Michelle: Who hasn't lost a cousin or two in their time?

Rita: Okay, okay. So, who agrees with Tiny Tears, who thinks we should go back?

(Erin and Clare raise their hands. Orla scratches her chin thoughtfully.)

Clare: Orla!

Orla: I like James, I like Take That more.

Rita: Make a fucking decision, I've t-shirts to flog!

Michelle: Come on, girls. It's Take That we're talking about!

Erin: I know, it's just

Michelle: You said it yourself, Erin, the greats don't come here. We never got to see Bros, New Kids on the Block, Right Said Fred.

(Rita rolls her eyes.)

Michelle: Let's not add Take That to the list. We can't turn back. There's too much at stake.

Erin: James has the tickets!

Michelle: Shit!

summary: James is helping the gypsies. Michelle wants him to get in the van. James is not leaving. James and Jonjo are arguing.
LLM_scene:
[Outside near the lane. A battered white van with ROMANIAN GYPSIES around it, packing belongings. James is helping lift blankets and crates. Michelle runs up panting.]

Michelle: James! Jesus, just get in the van, for God’s sake!

James: I’m not getting in any van. I'm helping these folks move their things, fair play.

Michelle: You heard what Jonjo said—he needs you behind the wheel before the crossroads, or we’ll be stopped.

Jonjo: (calling) You’re dawdlin’, lad! Ain’t got all day!

James: I’m busy! These gypsies asked for help—who am I to turn away?

Michelle: You’re my brother! And you promised me you’d protect us from trouble—not bring more.

James: Helping people ain’t trouble. It’s kindness. Something you’ve forgotten.

Jonjo: (stepping in) Kindness won’t stop the Garda checkpoint, will it? You think they’ll say “thanks for lending a hand”?

Michelle: Exactly! (turns to James) Every minute here’s risk.

James: (firm) I’ll risk it. They lost everything in the fire. And now you ask me to abandon them?

Michelle: They’re strangers, James. What about our safety? What about our future?

James: Our future is built on what we do now—if we abandon people now, we’ll regret it forever.

Jonjo: (losing patience) You’ll let sentry dogs tear apart the back of the van while you argue poetry?

Michelle: Stop talking in riddles, James! Get in that driver’s seat before—

James: No. I won’t. Not until everyone is safe inside. All of them.

Michelle: (exasperated) You’re impossible.

Orla: (walking out from house) What’s all the shouting?

Erin: Sounds like James is making a speech again.

Michelle: Orla, Erin, stay back. This is serious.

Erin: Serious or stupid? One word away between each, sometimes.

Jonjo: Look, Erin, Orla—help me load the last crate or go inside.

Erin: I ain't lifting crates for smugges.

Orla: Who are smugges?

Erin: Gypsies. Haven’t you ever seen a TV?

James: Enough! (“turns to Michelle”) I know you fear things gone wrong. But I can’t leave them waiting.

Michelle: You can’t stay either! We both could get in trouble.

James: Then we will. But you’ll see—history’ll judge us better for staying than for walking away.

Jonjo: Well, judge away, but you better be ready to drive like you mean it when I say go.

Michelle: (to James) When I say go, do it. No more speeches.

James: I'll be ready. (looks at the gypsies smiling at him) Let’s finish this—together.

[Michelle steps back, Jonjo returns to van, Erin and Orla watch. James lifts final crate.]

Jonjo: That’s the last one.

Michelle: Go. Drive.

James: Hold tight.

(The van door slams shut, Jonjo starts the engine, van pulls away slowly, James stands watching with Michelle.)
human_scene:
[At the gypsies' stall. The van pulls up. James is happily helping the gypsies.]

(Rita beeps the horn. Orla looks out the window at James while sucking a lollipop. Michelle opens the sliding door.)

Michelle: What are you playing at? Get in the van, fucko!

Gypsy: Does not have to if you don't want to, James.

Michelle: With all due respect, this has got nothing to do with you.

Gypsy: The way you treat this fella is disgraceful.

Michelle: What is going on, James?

James: Jonjo and the lads, well, they just get me, and it turns out, I'm a really good salesman.

Gypsy: He's a natural.

Michelle: So what? You're a gypsy now?

Erin: Traveller!

Gypsy: Actually, gypsy's fine.

Michelle: I knew it.

Rita: Let's get a move on!

Michelle: Right, get in the van. Come on. And do not test me, 'cause we've already missed PJ and Duncan.

Clare: Is that who was supporting them?

Michelle: Aye.

Clare: Oh, I really like them!

James: I'm not leaving, Michelle.

Michelle: Not even for Gary Barlow?

Gypsy: I don't really rate him as a songwriter, you know?

(James looks offended.)

James: I'm sorry, Jonjo, but you've just crossed the line there.

(James gets in the van with the others. Jonjo the gypsy looks devastated.)

summary: Erin, Orla, Michelle, Clare and James are going to the This and That concert. Mary will be calling their parents to let them go.
LLM_scene:
[In the Quinn kitchen. Erin, Orla, Michelle, Clare and James are stuffing stuff into bags.]

Erin: Right, girls, this is it — This and That concert tonight. I can’t believe we got tickets.

Orla: I’ve packed my good camera. If I don’t get at least one epic crowd shot, I’m returning to poverty.

Clare: And I’ve got enough eyeliner to black out an entire stadium.

James: You do realise I can’t see when you do that, right? I’ll probably trip over wires or something.

Michelle: Oh James, you’ll survive. As long as you don’t end up dragged onstage.

Erin: Just imagine all the banter. All the songs. ALL of it.

Mary: (from offstage) Ladies! What’s the state of this?

[Mary enters, holding her phone.]

Mary: I’ve to ring Gerry and Granda Joe. They need to agree you can go.

Erin: Mammy, you don’t think they’ll say no, do you?

Orla: I promise, we’ll be safe. Clare’s uncle is picking us up from the venue.

Clare: Yes, he has a car! Not one of yours that might fall apart halfway.

James: I’ll be with you the whole time. Pack of us, us five.

Mary: Fine, but I need to ‘sell’ it. They’ll think it’s all noise and bad influence.

Michelle: It’s This and That! It’s cultural enrichment! Music! Good vibrations!

Erin: If you say “good vibrations”, I’ll puke.

[Mary dials phone.]

Mary: Gerry? Hi love. I have a proposition.

Gerry: (voice via phone) What is it this time?

Mary: The girls want to go to a concert tonight — This and That band. Good bunch, Mary says.

Gerry: A concert? At this hour?

Mary: Yes love, I know. But Clare’s uncle will pick them up. James, too. I’ll be there early.

Gerry: (voice) What about Curfew? You’ll bring them home safe?

Mary: Of course. No risks with … noise and crowd.

[Erin exchanges relieved look with Orla, Michelle smiles.]

Gerry: (voice) Right. But tickets cost?

Mary: Already done.

Gerry: (voice) Then sure. Have fun — but I want updates every half hour.

Mary: You’ll get’em.

[Sister Michael’s old radio plays in background.]

Mary: Erin, be in by midnight.

Erin: Midnight. We’ll fly in then. Promise.

Orla: I’ll text if the concert turns into an apocalypse.

James: See you later Mam! Bye Clare! Let’s go tick off some concrete dancing.

[They all grab bags, head to door.]

Clare: Best night ever, you wretched lot.

Michelle: High on music and freedom.

Mary: (smiling) You lot better behave. And bring me back stories, not mess.

Erin: Always, Mam.

[They rush out the door, laughing. Mary watches them go, concerned but proud.]
human_scene:
[Time lapse.]

Erin: Wise up, Mammy! As if a polar bear's going to rock up at a Take That concert!

Orla: He wouldn't get a ticket, for a start. They sold out months ago.

Mary: You'd be surprised, girls.

Granda Joe: Aye, thon boys would get in where draughts wouldn't.

Gerry: Sure, the concert's nowhere near the zoo.

Granda Joe: But he's not in the zoo anymore, is he, simple Simon? He's sauntering about Belfast without a care in the world.

Sarah: Aye, keep up, Gerry.

Gerry: What I'm saying is that it would be quite a lot of ground for him to cover.

Mary: They're quick on their feet when they want to be, love.

Orla: Or someone might give him a lift.

Erin: Whose side are you on, Orla?

Michelle: Come on, Mary. If you won't let Erin go, our Mas won't let us go.

Mary: Well, neither they should! And I'll be ringing them to say as much.

(Michelle looks annoyed.)

Clare: (frantic) Oh, brilliant!

James: I hate my life.

Mary: Look girls, I know how much you were looking forward to seeing This and That.

Erin: Take That!

Mary: But there'll be other concerts.

Erin: No there won't! The fact that this one's happening is a miracle. Nobody good ever comes here 'cause we keep killing each other!

Sarah: And now we're overrun with polar bears.

Granda Joe: Where will it end?

Erin: Seriously?!

summary: Erin, Michelle, James, Clare and Orla are going to the concert. They are afraid of the polar bear but they are determined to go.
LLM_scene:
[Outside Erin’s house. The gang is gathered at the gate. It’s dusk.]

Erin: Right, is everyone ready? Tickets, phones, shoes—Orla, you got your gum?

Orla: Aye, I’ve got gum. But I’ve still got a bad feeling about that polar bear poster outside the concert hall. It’s huge.

Michelle: It’s only a picture, Orla. Polar bears don’t wander into gigs in Belfast.

James: You never know. Last time I went to a fair, a life-size dinosaur costume chased me.

Clare: Stop exaggerating, James. The polar bear is just part of the light show or something.

Erin: If he moves, I’m legging it. (pauses) But I’m going anyway. Aren’t we all?

Michelle: We are. We’re going. Fear of polar bears won’t stop us. Concert tickets cost money, Erin.

James: My Mum says if I survive the polar bear, I can have ice cream after.

Orla: See? Stakes are high. Very motivational.

Clare: Who’s meeting us at the venue? My Da said he’ll drop me off early.

Erin: I’ll pick you up on the way. Michelle and I are sharing the lift.

Michelle: With James in the backseat, singing half the drive—promise no bears in the back, okay?

James: I’ll behave—unless there’s an impromptu roar.

Orla: Let’s just promise to stick together, aye? If the polar bear show starts, we stay tight.

Erin: Deal. Now let’s go get dressed before the concert starts without us.

Clare: Wait—did anyone bring a jacket? Neon lights are cold.

Michelle: I’ve got Erin’s spare hoodie. Just in case.

Erin: Good—fear of polar bears and cold neon wind, but nothing’s stopping us tonight.

James: To the concert! And to the polar bear—may it stay on the poster.

Orla: (smiling) On the poster, it is. Let’s fly, you lot.
human_scene:
[In Erin's bedroom. The kids enter.]

Michelle: Well I'm not letting that fat, furry fuck ruin the biggest day of my life!

Erin: (sitting on her bed) What can we do?

(James, Clare and Orla sit on the bed beside Erin.)

Michelle: Right, listen, girls. I've never told anyone this before but sometimes when Robbie's being interviewed, it's like he's sending me messages through the TV, you know, like telepathically or whatever. It's like he's saying we're meant to be together.

Erin: Aye, maybe don't tell that to anyone again, Michelle. Ever.

Michelle: Look, this is too important. I'm going to that concert. I'm not afraid of a fucking polar bear!

Erin: Me either.

James: Nor me.

Michelle: Bastard!

Bill Clinton: Looking out over these historic walls, I see a peaceful city, a safe city, a hopeful city, full of young people that should have a peaceful and prosperous future here, where their roots and families are.

(The kids walk away from the crowd, arms around each other, smiling.)

Bill Clinton: That is what I see, today with you.

(The crowd cheers. Shot zooms in on TVs in a shop window, displaying Clinton.)

Bill Clinton: And so I ask you to build on the opportunity you have before you. To believe that the future can be better than the past. To work together because you have so much more to gain by working together than by drifting apart. Have the patience to work for a just and lasting peace.

summary: The President of the United States of America is coming to Derry tomorrow. Schools across the city are marking it as a public holiday. Sister Michael is worried that the visit will give the Pope ideas.
LLM_scene:
[INT. NOLAN KITCHEN – MORNING]

Erin: Mammy, the whole city’s buzzing—they’re closing schools tomorrow. The President of the United States is coming to Derry.

Mary: What? The President? Here?

Orla: Sure, Erin, who else could they mean? Obama? Trump? Some chap who sells burgers?

Erin: No, Orla—President of the USA. He’ll be visiting. Everything’s shut down.

Gerry: Public holiday, they’re saying. Every school. Mary, have you heard?

Mary: First I hear of it. And just when I found a decent bit of peace!

Granda Joe: And now they’ll crowd the streets, she’ll catch me without a hat—face sunburnt.

Sarah: Can’t be doing with that nonsense. And blocking off the roads and all that.

[INT. SISTER MICHAEL’S OFFICE – LATE MORNING]

Sister Michael: Entrance.

Mary: Morning, Sister Michael. We thought we’d see you about this new holiday business.

Sister Michael: Yes, well. The President coming is... monumental. But I’ve concerns.

Erin: What kind of concerns? Is the Pope visiting after him?

Sister Michael: Exactly my fear, Erin. Give the Pope ideas—next thing you know, rosaries everywhere, extra holy days, masses nonstop.

Granda Joe: That’d upset the balance.

Sarah: Mammy’s already frightened her garden shed will get converted into a chapel.

Mary: Sister Michael, sure we like our faith and all, but I don’t need the church running every minute of the clock.

Sister Michael: It’s about precedent. If we start closing schools for heads of state—

Erin: Mammy, you’ll get a lie in tomorrow!

Mary: Don’t you tempt me.

Orla: (licking spoon) Is there cake for this holiday? You know I celebrate with cake.

[They all look at Sister Michael.]

Sister Michael: I’ll speak to the bishop. Try to keep things under control. But yes—expect grand gestures.

Erin: Grand gestures? Mammy, gran, would you rather see the Pope or the President first?

Mary: Don’t be ridiculous, Erin. Both give me palpitations.
human_scene:
[Time lapse.]

Jenny: (singing) Christmas time.

Aisling: (singing) Silent night.

Jenny: (singing) Mistletoe and wine.

Aisling: (singing) Holy night.

Jenny: (singing) Children singing Christian rhyme.

Jenny and Aisling: (singing) With logs on the fire and gifts on the tree, a time to rejoice (Jenny shakes tamborine) in the good that we see. (Jenny hits triangle)

Michelle: That totally just wrecked my buzz.

Sister Michael: Great stuff altogether. A fitting rendition of what I consider to be the most God awful song ever written. Just one announcement today, girls. I'm sure many of you will have guessed what it's about. Although tomorrow is not officially a public holiday, schools across the city have decided to view it as such. Because tomorrow, the President of the United States of America is coming here, to Derry.

(Clare smiles with delight.)

Sister Michael: You're a little young to perhaps understand the enormity of this. A few short months ago, this would have been unimaginable.

(Erin smiles proudly.)

Sister Michael: But here we are. And I for one can barely believe it.

(Michelle and James smile.)

Sister Michael: I mean, people in this place stop killing each other for five minutes and the whole world loses the absolute run of itself! This visit concerns me for a number of reasons, girls, but mostly because I am scared it will give the Pope ideas, and that's the last thing I need. No. Our Lady Immaculate will play no part in this farce. And I expect to see you all here tomorrow morning, business as usual. Is that clear?

(Silence.)

Sister Michael: Is. That. Clear?!

Crowd: (miserably) Yes, Sister Michael.

Sister Michael: (blesses herself) The Father, Son, Holy Spirit.

summary: Clare, Michelle, Erin, Orla and James are angry at Chelsea. They are planning to play truant in protest against her.
LLM_scene:
[In the Quinn kitchen. Clare, Michelle, Erin, Orla and James clustered around the table. James tapping angrily on mug; Orla reading something on phone.]

Erin: I’m telling you, she’s gone too far this time. Chelsea thinks she's queen of the school.

Clare: Aye, and we’re the peasants in her court. It’s not fair.

Michelle: She was slaggin’ me in front of everyone yesterday. Said I look like I slept in my uniform.

James: She’s been acting the maggot since the start of term.

Orla: Fine, what are we doing about it? Complaining never worked before.

Erin: We’ll teach her a lesson. A lesson she’ll never forget.

Clare: Are you thinkin’ what I’m thinkin’?

Michelle: Sicknote from Mam? Disappearing to the loo forever?

James: No. Truant.

Orla: You mean… skip school? All of us?

Erin: A protest. We don’t go in. Not one of us. She won’t know what hit her.

James: My Ma’ll kill me.

Clare: She won’t know where I am, anyway. Trust me, I’ve got it sorted.

Michelle: And what about homework? Teachers notice absence.

Erin: We’ll tell ‘em we’re sick. All of us. A grand conspiracy.

Orla: I like this. Feels revolting but... cathartic.

James: I’m in. But where do we go?

Clare: To the common area near the bridge. Sit comfy, bring snacks. Make a scene.

Michelle: Brilliant. Public protest truanting. As if!

Erin: We’ll take signs. “Chelsea’s Cruelty Off Duty”, that sort of thing.

Orla: I’ll make flyers on my phone. With Chelsea’s face and slogans.

James: You’re savage, Orla.

Erin: Don’t worry, we’re not cruel. Just making a point.

Clare: So tomorrow, first bell, not there. Got it?

All together: Got it.

Michelle: Erin—

Erin: Yeah?

Michelle: Promise you’ll stay with us. No backing off.

Erin: Promise.

Orla: God, I can’t wait to see the look on her face.

James: This is going to be epic.

[They lean in, whispering excitedly, plotting.]

Clare: Everyone ready? Tomorrow morning… revolution.
human_scene:
[In the corridor.]

Clare: She can't do this. She simply cannot do this.

Michelle: Well, she's done it, Clare.

Clare: But it's history! She's making us miss history!

Orla: Och, but I really wanted to find out what that Cromwell fella got up to next. I really enjoy him!

Clare: Not history class, Orla. Real history. History being made!

Erin: And Irish people aren't allowed to enjoy Oliver Cromwell, Orla.

Orla: Why?

Michelle: Because he was a fucking arsehole!

James: Look, Bill doesn't even get here until four o'clock tomorrow.

Michelle: "Bill"? Who are you, his ma?

James: We've got plenty of time, is all I'm saying.

Clare: Do you know how packed that Guildhall Square is gonna be, James? You'd have to camp overnight just to get a glimpse of him.

Erin: Chelsea will sort us out.

Clare: Och, I'm not even sure I trust Chelsea anymore!

Michelle: Aye, Chelsea might be flaky.

Orla: She does have crafty eyes.

Erin: Okay, I'm not comfortbale with the Chelsea-bashing, girls.

Clare: This is the biggest thing that's ever happened here. That's ever likely to happen here. We should be a part of it!

Michelle: We will be.

Clare: Are you suggesting we play truant?

Michelle: Okay, normal people don't call it that, but yes, yes I am.

Clare: You know what, girls? Sometimes, in order to do the right thing, you have to do the wrong thing. And on this occasion, right is wrong, and wrong is right!

Michelle: What the fuck are you on about? Are you gonna sack off school or not?

Clare: Let's do it!

summary: Gerry, Jim, Joe and Colm are in the car. They are wondering why Bill Clinton was brought to Burt. Uncle Colm explains that he is American's thirty-fifth president, whereas JFK was the twenty-eighth.
LLM_scene:
[Inside Gerry’s old hatchback, afternoon. Gerry is driving. Jim in front passenger seat. Joe and Uncle Colm in the back.]

Gerry: So, I still don’t get it – why’d they bring Bill Clinton to Burt’s funeral?

Jim: Aye, Gerry, sure I thought he was still President or something spectacular like that.

Joe: Clinton’s from over there, is he? America, isn’t it? What business has he got with Burt?

Colm: Right, lads. Settle down. Bill Clinton was the thirty‐fifth President of the United States.

Jim: Thirty‐fifth, you say? Didn’t JFK get shot? He was like number… what was he?

Colm: JFK was the twenty‐eighth. Thirty‐fifth was Clinton—William Jefferson Clinton, served 1993 to 2001.

Gerry: Jesus, Colm, you're like a walking history book. So Clinton’s way after Kennedy.

Joe: I thought Kennedy was like, after World War II, but before Vietnam?

Jim: Exactly, Joe. Kennedy was much earlier. Clinton won later elections. So what’s the link with Burt now?

Colm: Well, that’s the thing – there’s no real link. They brought Clinton ’cause Burt was big on charity, had connections. They wanted someone international.

Gerry: Charity, fair enough. But still, seems a bit over the top.

Jim: Ye think maybe they just wanted the prestige? A big name to show they mean business.

Joe: Or maybe Burt paid for it. That kind of funeral don’t come cheap with ex‐Presidents turning up.

Colm: Could be any of those. But bring it back home – makes us wonder about our own politics, our own leaders.

Gerry: True enough. Though I’ll never understand why Americans number their Presidents the way Colm just did.

Jim: It’s like collecting football cards, but you're voting them in instead of trading them.

Joe: Next thing you know, they’ll be giving numbers to pets. “This is Rufus, he’s the forty-second dog of the house.”

Colm: (laughs) Right, that I’d pay to see. But let's just say, Clinton being thirty-fifth and JFK being twenty-eighth – that’s how the lineage runs. And Burt wanted to honour that kind of legacy.
human_scene:
[In the car. Gerry is driving. Jim in the passenger seat. Joe and Colm are in the back. It is dark outside.]

(They drive past a sign saying 'WELCOME TO BURT'.)

Gerry: It just doesn't make any sense, Jim.

Jim: I heard him say it. As clear as day, it was.

Gerry: Burt? Why would they bring him to Burt?

Jim: Well that's what's so clever about it. Nobody's going to go looking for the president of the USA in Burt, now, are they? Sure, if you went about saying Bill Clinton was in Burt, people would think you were clean mad.

Gerry: Precisely. Look, lads, if you want my opinion...

Granda Joe: We don't!

Gerry: Grand.

Uncle Colm: This Clinton boyo is actually American's fourty-second president, which is interesting now, because JFK, well, he was the thirty-fifth.

Granda Joe: Why is that interesting?

Uncle Colm: Well, it's not really, I suppose. Sometimes I'll just say something to get me from one sentence to the other, Joe. You know how it is.

Jim: It should be just up here on the left.

Uncle Colm: I'm not sure what number Nixon was, now, or the man, what do you call him? The beardy fella in the hat. The one that knocked the oul slavery on the head?

Gerry: Lincoln.

Uncle Colm: The very boy. But then there was the twenty-seventh...

summary: Gerry and Granda Joe are driving back from Roscarna Road. They pass the same 'WELCOME TO BURT' sign that they passed the previous night. They are back in the same place.
LLM_scene:
[In Gerry’s car, evening. Gerry driving, Granda Joe in the passenger seat. They pass the “WELCOME TO BURT” sign.]

Gerry: There it is again. Welcome to Burt. You’d think by now I’d know the place like the back of me hand.

Granda Joe: (peering out) That sign looks the same as last night, Gerry. Maybe we’re stuck in a loop.

Gerry: Oh come on, Joe. Don’t start with your conspiracy theories now.

Granda Joe: I’m only saying. The road looked different, the lamp posts new. Or maybe it’s just my eyesight.

Gerry: Probably your eyesight. Or your head. Did you sleep at all?

Granda Joe: Slept like a baby. Woke up every two hours screaming.

Gerry: (sighs) You had the fire alarm in your dreams again.

Granda Joe: I told you, it wasn’t a dream. I could hear bombs.

Gerry: Bombs? This isn’t Belfast, Joe.

Granda Joe: In my mind it is. These roads, these signs — they all bring me back.

Gerry: You’re too old for this, Pops.

Granda Joe: And what about you, Gerry? You think I’m the only one haunted?

Gerry: I’m just glad the girls are asleep. If Erin saw this sign again, she’d have something to say.

Granda Joe: Orla’d probably write a poem. Erin’d want to debate it.

Gerry: That’s exactly it. Erin—always with her arguing, her questions. You never quiet are you, Erin?

Granda Joe: Not like me. I’m quiet now. Quiet is dangerous.

Gerry: (glancing at him) You still planning on going to Roscarna Road tomorrow?

Granda Joe: Aye. Something didn’t sit right with me there.

Gerry: You think there’s more to this place than just memories and walls?

Granda Joe: There’s always more, son. Always more.

Gerry: (pulling over) I’ll stop. You want a cigarette?

Granda Joe: If you like. Let’s sit here a moment. Look at that sign again. Let it sink in.

Gerry: (turns off engine) Welcome to Burt.

Granda Joe: (softly) Welcome home.
human_scene:
[Time lapse. It is morning. Joe has fallen asleep.]

Uncle Colm: America's thirtieth. And then there was the lad they named all the vacuum cleaners after.

Gerry: Jesus wept. How much further, Jim?

Jim: It should be just up here on the left.

(They pass the same 'WELCOME TO BURT' sign that they passed the previous night.)

Gerry: We're back in the same place.

Uncle Colm: And Kennedy, of course, the poor critter.

Gerry: How?

Uncle Colm: Lovely fella. Hands on him like shovels.

Gerry: How the feck are we back in the same fecking place?!

Granda Joe: (waking up) What's going on?

Gerry: I've driven one-hundred-and-seventy-eight miles and I'm back where I was five fecking hours ago, Joe, that's what's going on!

Granda Joe: You stupid bloody eejit!

Uncle Colm: Thon Reagan character, he was another.

Gerry: (furious) STOP LISTING PRESIDENTS, COLM!!

Granda Joe: He'll list presidents if he wants to list presidents!

Jim: Aw, there it is! Roscarna Road! That's it! That's what they said!

Granda Joe: Well spotted, Jim.

Uncle Colm: Good man yourself, Jim.

Gerry: (sarcastic) Where would we be without you, Jim?
